I'll have to wait for a pypy with psycopg2 support... compiling and all that is too time consuming and since I haven't done it before, it's likely to take me plenty of time...
@Kronuz what platform?  I have a precompiled pypy-postgresql for 32-bit linux if you want it (I can also do 64-bit linux as needed)
@alex I'm on a Mac OS X 10.6 (64 bits)
unfortunately I can't translate for that platform, sorry
What are the dependencies to compile pypy ...what are the steps? ...is it difficult?
the process is checkout my repo then; `pypy/translator/goal/translate.py -Ojit pypy/translator/goal/targetpypystandalone.py --withmod-postgresql`
you'll need 4GB of RAM I think
andyou'll need the postgresql headers installed, I think that's it
http://doc.pypy.org/en/latest/getting-started-python.html#translating-the-pypy-python-interpreter has some more details
don't use the exact final command it has though, or you wont get hte psycopg2 lib
@alex. What flags do you use I have OSX 10.6 and I'm getting libssl errors?
flags for what?
4 gigs of ram?
Did you set LDFLAGS or anything. Like I said I'm getting libssl errors from a stock OSX install.
@jessenoller on 64-bit, yes.  this is why we try to keep nightly available for as many platforms as we can
Sweet baby Jesus
@jessenoller you don't need to translate to test every change, that's what tests are for :)
If any of you python people can take a minute to fill out a survey on why you are or aren't using PyPy, we'd be very appreciative: http://morepypy.blogspot.com/2011/05/pypy-usage-survey.html
niiice....I definitelly need to test django on pypy. Anyone knows if those buggy DB drivers are working properly now? specially mysql and postgres.  Also anyone worked with mongo db and pypy ?

@alex just released mysql-ctypes recently: https://github.com/quora/mysql-ctypes so mysql should work fine with pypy now. I'm pretty sure postgres works on pypy too. Here's a summary of what works and what doesn't: http://reinout.vanrees.org/weblog/2011/06/06/django-and-pypy.html
thanks for your reply @streeter  ... in my work we are seriously considering moving things to django and runing it on pypy
